thread.title: MENIFEE: Seasoned council candidates seek open seat
thread.title_full: MENIFEE: Seasoned council candidates seek open seat - Press Enterprise

author: TOM SHERIDAN
title: MENIFEE: Seasoned council candidates seek open seat
text:
By TOM SHERIDAN / STAFF 16, 2015 Updated: 5:57 p.m. MENIFEE: Seasoned council candidates seek open seat 1 of 5 More Four candidates are running in a special election to choose a new member of the Menifee City Council. FRANK BELLINO, FILE PHOTO Related article » MENIFEE CITY COUNCIL Four candidates are running in the Nov. 3 election to replace the late Wally Edgerton, who represented District 3.
STU BLAZE
Age: 58
Family: Married, five children, four grandchildren
Occupation: Franchise and management consultant
Education: San Diego Patrick Henry High School; attended Grossmont
College
Community service: Board member, Menifee Valley Chamber of Commerce; president-elect, Menifee Rotary
Campaign phone: 619-913-9222
DARCY KUENZI
Age: 52
Family: Married, three children
Occupation: Government affairs manager
Education: Certificate of achievement, accounting, Palomar College; attended the University of San Diego and UCLA
Community service: Menifee City Councilwoman, 2008-'12; president, Menifee Valley Community Cupboard; founding boardmember the SWAN Foundation; and former Riverside County Transportation Commissioner
Campaign phone/website: 951-961-9042 or face
book.com/IheartMenifee
LESA
SOBEK
Age: 57
Family: Married, three children, 11 grandchildren
Occupation: Planning commissioner
Education: Graduated from Riverside La Sierra High School; attended Riverside Community College
Community service: Founded GREAT (Grandparents reading, enriching and tutoring) literacy program in the Menifee Union School District; initiated Menifee Military Banner Program honoring military members with street banners and organized Menifee Better Together neighborhood revitalization effort
Campaign phone/website: 909-838-3774 and face book.com/lesasobekfor citycouncil 2015
NEIL
WINTER
Age: 61
Family: Married, two children, two grandchildren
Occupation: Retired businessman
Education: B.A., political science, Cal Poly Pomona
Community service: none
Campaign phone/website: 949-280-2340 and
facebook.com/ neil.winter.71
The nearly 9,000 voters in the Menifee’s District 3 City Council race will choose from four experienced candidates to finish out the term of the late Wally Edgerton.
Edgerton, the city’s first mayor and a member of the City Council since it incorporated in October 2008, died in May following a lengthy battle with liver disease. He was 81.
Menifee’s City Council voted in June to hold a special election rather than appoint a replacement for Edgerton’s term, which expires in December 2016.
The special election is Nov. 3. According to a city staff report the election will cost approximately $25,000.
Only voters in the District 3 voting area – roughly the southeast quadrant of the city – can participate. City Clerk Kathy Bennett said 8,856 voters are registered in the district as of Friday.
Menifee’s population now exceeds 85,000, a nearly 30 percent increase since it incorporated seven years ago. And at a recent candidates forum, speakers noted that the median age has dropped from 58 to 38 in that time.
Prior to this election, businessman Stu Blaze’s biggest contribution to the city was bringing the Breakfast Club of Menifee diner to town. Blaze, 58, noted that project broke ground in 2008 during the throes of the recession.
“We did it in Menifee because we live here,” Blaze said. “We thought the city needed something like that. And we were correct.”
Aaron Park, Blaze’s campaign manager, said the restaurant attracts as many as 4,000 customers weekly. Blaze said he is no longer involved in the operation of the Breakfast Club but that he now wants to put his experience to work on the City Council.
“I want to be part of ensuring the growth in the city is balanced,” Blaze said. “I know why businesses come to cities.”
Darcy Kuenzi has been a resident in the Menifee area for 23 years and was a member of the original City Council. In 2012, Scott Mann defeated her in the mayoral election.
“I am back for more,” said Kuenzi, 52, who is a gov ernment affairs officer for the Riverside County Flood Control and Water Conservation District.
Public safety and traffic are two issues that Kuenzi said are on the minds of res idents. Securing financing for future road projects is a critical job for the council, as is working on a new model for the funding of public safety services, she said.
“I have a proven record of common sense solutions and doing heavy lifting for the city,” Kuenzi said.
Like Kuenzi, Lesa Sobek has lived in the area for over 20 years, long before it was known as Menifee. A member of the planning commission since 2013, Sobek’s history of community involvement dates back to her earliest days here, after she and her husband moved from Riverside.
